Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Foundations of robust surface parametrization and resampling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Processing 3D shape information (geometry) efficiently is crucial for many domains: for example, computer-aided design, scientific computing, urban planning and cultural heritage preservation. The amount of geometric data generated and stored is rapidly increasing. The most common way to represent geometric data is with unstructured meshes. Unstructured meshes enjoy many attractive features, but inherently limit the efficiency and accuracy of many algorithms for geometry processing and physical simulation, as well as compactness of representations, compared to image processing algorithms. Mesh parametrization is the fundamental geometric processing technique used both in the context of converting surfaces to image-like representations, and for mapping data to surfaces. While significant progress has been made in the development of high-quality global parametrization algorithms a number of important questions are unresolved, limiting the potentially broad applicability of these techniques.

This exploratory project is developing mathematical and algorithmic bases for controlling global parametrization quality as well as limiting the possible amount of local distortion. The techniques being developed, based on the theory of quasiconformal maps and efficient greedy optimization algorithms, will serve as a foundation for future work on robust, high-quality and scalable global parametrization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Efficient and reliable processing of geometry is crucial for many domains: computer-aided design, scientific computing, urban planning, cultural heritage preservation, to name just a few.  Raw geometric data comes in a variety of forms (range images, LIDAR data, volumetric data) and most commonly is converted to unstructured meshes. Unstructured meshes nave many attractive features, but inherently limit efficiency and accuracy of many algorithms for processing and physical simulation,  and make multiscale processing complicated. Surface parametrization is the fundamental technique used both for resampling surfaces on regular grids, or collections of image-like regular domains, enabling use of much more powerful signal processing and PDE techniques.  This has impact on all application areas where computation on complex surface domains is used. 

Over the past several years fundamental understanding of the parameterization problem  and its connections to many important concepts in differential and conformal geometry has been improving rapidly, leading to many novel algorithms. Yet many important questions remain, primarily related to development of reliable and efficient algorithms, capable of handling arbitrary geometric inputs in an automatic manner (robust algorithms). In this project we have developed several techniques making progress in this direction. Specifically,  we have developed an algorithm that, for an important class of problems guarantees (up to possible problems related to floating-point roundoff error) that a valid solution is computed. Another algorithm applicable to a majority of practical cases, while lacking full desirable guarantees,nevertheless, does produce a valid result, in rare cases requiring minor adjustments to user input.In the process, important insights were gained into the fundamentals of the problem, creating a foundationfor further advances in a subsequent project. We have also developed a new approach to measuring and optimizing parameterization quality (strict minimizers) that has implications for other geometric problems, for example, 2D and 3D deformations.
